 | Name = Gangrene Image = GangreneFoot.JPG Caption = Dry gangrene of the 1st to
 | 4th toes of the right foot in a man with diabetes. DiseasesDB = 19273 ICD10 =

}} 'Gangrene' is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition that
arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis). {{cite book
  | last=Porth first = Carol title = Essentials of pathophysiology publisher =
  | Lippincott Williams & Wilkins year = 2007 page = 41 url = http://books.google.com/?id=57RQC-
  | 3OPtUC&pg=PT59&dq=necrosis+gangrene&q=necrosis%20gangrene accessdate = 2010-06-
  | 15 isbn = 978-0-7817-7087-3}} {{Cite web title =
  | Gangrene â Introduction work = NHS Health AâZ publisher = NHS url =
  | http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/gangrene/Pages/Introduction.aspx accessdate =
  | 2010-06-15 }} This may occur after an injury or infection, or in
  | people suffering from any chronic health problem affecting blood
  | circulation. The primary cause of gangrene is reduced
  | blood supply to the affected tissues, which results in cell death. Diabetes and long-term smoking increase the risk of
  | suffering from gangrene. {{Cite web

  | title = Gangrene â Causes work = NHS Health AâZ publisher = National
  | Health Service (England) url =
  | http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Gangrene/Pages/Causes.aspx accessdate = 2010-06-
  | 15 }}

There are different types of gangrene with different symptoms, such as dry
gangrene, wet gangrene, gas gangrene, internal gangrene and necrotizing
fasciitis. Treatment options include
debridement (or, in severe cases, amputation) of the affected body parts,
antibiotics, vascular surgery, maggot therapy or hyperbaric oxygen therapy. {{Cite web
  | title = Gangrene â Treatment work = NHS Health AâZ publisher = National
  | Health Service (England) url =
  | http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Gangrene/Pages/new_Treatment.aspx accessdate =
  | 2010-06-15 }}
